Award.AwardTitle: Testing the Impact of Race on Jury Evaluations of Informants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
An important body of legal scholarship has emerged about the justice risks associated with the use of informants, who provide information to law enforcement officials about criminal activity usually in exchange for leniency consideration or dismissal on a pending criminal charge. Despite the increasing concern, there has been very little empirical research on the use of informants as witnesses. This study builds on the nascent line of research about informant testimony by examining whether and how the race of the informant, as well as the race of the defendant, impacts laypersons' assessments of credibility, culpability, and blame-worthiness in a simulated jury setting. By measuring both individual-level and group-level cognition and action, the project tests how racism emerges and is elaborated in group-level judgment contexts, and how the race of case actors interacts with jurors' racial identity. Within that, the study will examine both the cognitive and more emotionally-based responses to informant testimony. The proposed research has the potential to generate timely and important broader impacts. It will inform policy regarding the use of informants and whether the documented problems with laypersons' assessments of informant evidence are exacerbated by the racial identify of those witness. As such, it has the potential to address real-word procedural issues that come from heavy reliance upon informants in drug case prosecutions. The broader impacts also include training and education of graduate and undergraduate students.

The study uses an experimental design, in which the race of defendant (African-American or white) and race of informant witness (African-American or white) is varied, creating four versions of an audio-visual presentation of a federal drug conspiracy trial that includes testimony by an informant. Jury-eligible, non-student adult participants will be recruited and assigned to 140 small group "juries." Each jury group will view one of the four versions of the trial and will then deliberate to determine a verdict. Those deliberations will be recorded to analyze the group decision-making process. After the verdict is rendered, participants will individually complete a comprehensive set of measures regarding decision-making processes, perceptions, and attitudes. The main research questions to be answered in this study are: 1) Is an African-American defendant more likely to be found guilty than a white defendant? 2) Are the credibility ratings for a white informant higher than for an African-American informant? 3) Is the credibility "threshold" for conviction lower for an African-American defendant than for a white defendant, as a function of differential empathy? 4) Will the group deliberation process amplify racial bias, as has been demonstrated in previous research on death penalty decision-making? And 5) Will the effects of informant/defendant race be moderated by juror race and gender?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concerns have grown in the legal and public arenas about the reliance on informants within the criminal justice system, due in part to the significant number of wrongful convictions involving informant testimony, and out of concern that heavy reliance upon informants in criminal cases erodes the legitimacy of the legal system more generally. The practice of using informants is particularly prevalent in drug cases, where law enforcement officials often exchange reduced or no charges, or lenient sentences, for assistance from arrestees in setting up others, and/or for testifying against others charged with drug crimes. This NSF-funded project was designed to extend research on how informant testimony is understood by jurors who are tasked with assessing it in criminal trials. Building on research showing that informant evidence is powerfully influential in judgments made by “mock” jurors, this study examined how race of defendant and race of informant impacts those judgments, and how those judgment processes interact with juror race and jury racial composition.  

Utilizing an experimental design, the study used a realistic audio-visual trial presentation with a case scenario to test how race of defendant (black or white), race of informant-witness (black or white) and individual juror and jury group racial characteristics interact in assessing evidence and determining verdict. Participants viewed a federal drug trafficking conspiracy case that included testimony by a co-conspirator who became an informant to reduce his punishment, the informant’s FBI “handler” who set up the defendant’s arrest, and a CHP patrol officer who initiated the defendant’s arrest.  Because proactive drug arrests like the scenario presented are highly dependent upon the believability of law enforcement and their informants to obtain a conviction, these case facts were ideal for exploring how jurors’ perceptions of credibility interacted with race. 822 jury-eligible adults participated in this study, who took on the role of juror in one of 144 jury groups. A racially and ethnically diverse participant pool was recruit to examine how jurors’ racial identities may impact judgment processes. The groups were randomly assigned to the different experimental conditions, and after viewing the trial presentation, they deliberated to verdict. After deliberations, participants completed an additional set of measures assessing their individual views on the evidence, perceptions of the defendant and informant, understanding of the jury instructions, attitudes about a number of social issues, and a series of demographic items.

 

Two competing hypotheses were tested in the main analysis: that juror racial bias would result in more guilty verdicts for the black defendant relative to the white defendant, especially among white defendants; or, alternatively, that skepticism about the fairness of the police and the criminal justice system would result in fewer guilty verdicts for the black defendant. The findings were consistent with the latter hypothesis. The black defendant acquitted more frequently than the white defendant across all conditions, and that effect was enhanced by deliberations. Moreover, credibility measures of the informant and law enforcement witnesses suggested that perceptions about law enforcement legitimacy played a role in judgment, as participants found these witnesses less credible when the defendant was black compared to when he was white. While white participants were more likely to convict across conditions compared to nonwhite participants, that race effect was largely driven by differential views of credibility. And although informant credibility was an important determinant of outcome, informant race had no impact on judgment. The deliberations data further supported these findings, suggesting that participants’ views of police legitimacy and fairness not only extended to their views of the informant, but also appeared to play a key role in whether the groups decided to acquit or convict the defendant.

In addition to the intellectual contributions of this project, it also provided training opportunities for both undergraduate students and doctoral students in Criminology, Law & Society and Psychological Science at UC Irvine. Both undergraduates and doctoral students presented findings at conferences and university convenings; one undergraduate produced an undergraduate honors’ thesis from his work on the project; and one doctoral student developed her dissertation research to further explore the impact of informant testimony on juror judgment. Three of the four undergraduates who participated in the REU component of the study went on to pursue graduate degrees. Two doctoral students have also had opportunities to co-author manuscripts for peer-reviewed publications reporting on findings from this project.
